document_title: Benign kidney tumors: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
To diagnose benign kidney tumors, doctors use many different methods. The key to diagnosis is determining whether the tumor is benign or malignant. Clinical and paraclinical methods are performed as follows:
Clinical examination
The doctor may start with a physical examination and collecting medical history, discussing the symptoms the patient is experiencing.
Paraclinical diagnosis; Blood tests evaluate kidney function through indicators: creatinine, urea, uric acid...; Urine analysis to find red blood cells, white blood cells, adrenal hormone levels...; Ultrasound to evaluate the number, size, structure of tumors...; Computed tomography (CT scan) helps determine the characteristics of benign kidney tumors, the functioning of the remaining kidney...; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET) are also indicated to check the location, size, and nature of the tumor; Nephrography with contrast helps to look for compression on the kidney parenchyma and distinguish it from other kidney diseases, specifically hydronephrosis; Genetic testing may be indicated to determine risk factors for benign kidney tumors, especially for Familial Polyp Syndrome and hereditary multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.; Kidney tumor biopsy to diagnose benign or malignant kidney tumors, helping doctors come up with appropriate treatment plans.
